The cells of B. chungangensis are rod-shaped, measuring approximately 0.5-0.7 μm in width and 1.3-3.5 μm in length. This bacterium is capable of forming oval-shaped endospores, which are resistant structures that allow the organism to survive under adverse environmental conditions.

Phylogenetically, B. chungangensis belongs to the genus Bacillus, which is a well-known group of bacteria known for their ability to produce endospores and their versatile metabolic capabilities. Biochemical and genetic analyses have revealed that B. chungangensis is closely related to other Bacillus species, such as Bacillus cereus and Bacillus thuringiensis, but it can be distinguished from them based on its unique phenotypic and genotypic characteristics.

B. chungangensis is considered a non-pathogenic bacterium, and its potential applications in various fields, such as agriculture, industry, and bioremediation, are currently being explored through further research and investigation.
